Graphical abstract The high-power-density aqueous Zn-NO3 − batteries are constructed. The mechanistic insights into enhanced electrocatalytic nitrate-to-ammonia conversion at multiphase interfaces include interfaces optimizing adsorption via electronic tuning, Co→O polarization boosting NO3 − activation, and core-satellite synergistic catalysis. The nitrate reduction via electrochemical catalysis offers an environmentally friendly method for sustainable ammonia production and wastewater remediation. However, conventional Co-based catalysts suffer from a major limitation: their nitrate (NO3 −) adsorption capacity remains weak. This drawback severely restricts their catalytic efficiency. To overcome this limitation, we synthesized a triphasic interface material (Cu/Co/CoO@C) via rapid joule heating and elucidated its performance-enhancing mechanisms. The exceptional catalytic performance originates from the phase interface-induced multiscale structural regulation. At the microscopic scale, electronic structure modulation through interfacial charge redistribution between Cu and Co/CoO significantly reduces intermediate adsorption energies. Co 3d and O 2p orbitals coupling generates a localized polarized electric field, enhancing NO3 − activation. At the macroscopic scale, defect-rich structures improve mass transfer and expose abundant active sites. With the Cu/Co/CoO@C, the yield of NH3 is achieved to 2.03 mmol h−1 cm−2 (−0.4 V vs. RHE, Faradaic efficiency (FE) 98.4 %). The assembled Zn-NO3 − battery delivered a maximum power density of 52.09 mW cm−2 and a NH3 production rate of 297.5 µmol h−1 cm−2 (FE 95.4 %). Based on these results, this work offers new insights into multiphase interface design. Keywords Multi-phase interface Electronic modulation P-d orbital coupling Core-satellite structure Zn-NO3 − battery 1 Introduction Production of NH3 is pretty meaningful for fertilizer manufacturing, chemical synthesis, and pharmaceutical production. Additionally, its potential as a carbon-neutral energy vector has been increasingly investigated in recent years [1–5]. Recently, electrochemical nitrate reduction to ammonia (NO3RR) has gained significant research interest. This approach stands out for its dual advantages of environmental sustainability and economic viability [6–8]. Among various catalysts, cobalt-based systems have drawn particular attention in NO3RR studies. Their exceptional selectivity toward NH4 + formation makes them particularly valuable for this process [9]. However, their weak adsorption for NO3 − limits the catalytic efficiency [10]. Thus, researchers have modified Co-based catalysts through multiple strategies, such as doping [11,12], morphology engineering [13–15], modification [16–18], alloying [19–21], and heterointerface construction [22,23]. Especially, the interfaces of electrocatalysts can significantly promote the reactional activity and selectivity through synergistic effects between different components [24,25]. By adjusting the electronic configuration of surface active sites, the spontaneous electron transfer plays an interesting role in lowering barriers of reaction [26,27]. Additionally, it enhances interfacial charge transfer kinetics, thereby significantly improving catalytic activity [28,29]. Despite significant progress, several challenges remain. (i) Most studies focus on single-phase and dual-phase interfaces [30–32]. Could triple-phase or multi-phase interfaces exhibit superior performance? (ii) Different interface structures may exhibit distinct functional properties in catalytic reactions, yet their specific roles are not elucidated. (iii) The microscopic mechanisms underlying interface-induced regulation of catalytic performance remain poorly understood. However, studies on multi-phase interfaces have rarely been reported. Therefore, understanding the microscopic mechanisms behind the enhanced performance of multiphase interface materials and fully exploiting their catalytic potential are critically important. Hence, to address these challenges, this study proposes a multiphase interface engineering strategy. Tri-phase (Cu/Co/CoO@C), dual-phase (Co/CoO@C), and single-phase (Cu@C) interface materials are synthesized using rapid Joule heating. The origins of performance differences among these materials were investigated through experiments. The results of operando characterization and density function theory (DFT) calculations demonstrate that this triphasic interface material possesses the following key advantages. (i) Electronic structure modulation, the electronic structure of catalytic centers is modulated through interfacial electronic interactions in the multiphase system, resulting in optimized adsorption-free energy of reaction intermediates. Meanwhile, competitive side reactions are significantly suppressed. (ii) p-d orbital coupling, strong p-d orbital (Co 3d & O 2p) coupling is observed, leading to significant orbital hybridization. This interaction induces interfacial Co → O electron transfer, resulting in the generation of a localized polarized electric field. This charge redistribution enhances NO3 − activation and accelerates subsequent reaction steps. (iii) Core-satellite synergistic catalysis, experimental results demonstrate that the unique core-satellite structure of the tri-phase interface material enables a synergistic catalytic mechanism. The core (Cu) and satellite (Co/CoO) active sites dominate the NO3 − → NO2 − and NO2 − → NH4 + reaction stages, respectively, ensuring highly efficient ammonia production. Our in-depth investigations have elucidated the microscopic mechanisms behind the enhanced performance of multiphasic interface materials, while revealing the distinctive functionalities of different interfaces. Compared to traditional long-duration heating methods, this technique requires only a few seconds to achieve stable multi-phase interface materials at 1600 °C. At −0.4 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), an ammonia production rate of 2.03 mmol h−1 cm−2 was achieved with 98.4 % Faradaic efficiency (FE). A battery (Zn-NO3 −) was assembled and tested with Cu/CoCoO@C. It is worth noting that the battery demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance with a peak power density of 52.09 mW cm−2. A NH3 production rate of 297.5 µmol h−1 cm−2 was found with 95.4 % FE. These findings advance fundamental understanding of structure-activity relationships in multiphase interface catalysts while providing new insights into high-efficiency electrocatalysts in the sustainable synthesis of NH3. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts 100 mg of conductive carbon black was added to a mixture solution with a specific volume (Cu: Co = 1:1) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution (0.2 M), Co(NO3)2·6H2O solution (0.2 M), and 2-methylimidazole ethanol solution (C4H6N2, 0.8 M). The mixture was stirred for 10 min to ensure uniform dispersion. Subsequently, the mixed solution was placed in an oven at 80 °C and dried overnight. After drying, the material was thoroughly ground for further use. Using a CIS-JH3.3-P joule heating device (In situ High-tech), the material was rapidly heated to 1600 °C under an Ar atmosphere to prepare the Cu/Co/CoO@C. Before testing and characterization, catalysts were rinsed 3 times with deionized water and EtOH. The other catalysts were prepared with the same method but with different precursors (Cu@C: Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Co/CoO@C: Co(NO3)2·6H2O). 2.2 Characterization Material morphology and composition were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Talos F200X, 200 kV) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted on a Rigaku SmartLab SE diffractometer with Cu-K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV and 50 mA. Surface chemical composition was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+), using the C 1s peak (284.8 eV) for binding energy calibration. Reaction intermediates were monitored by Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo NICOLET iS50). In situ Raman spectra were acquired using a confocal microscopy system (HORIBA LABRAM HR EVO). X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements were performed with a RapidXAFS 2 M spectrometer (Anhui Absorption Spectroscopy Analysis Instrument Co., Ltd.) in transmission or fluorescence mode (10 kV, 20 mA), with data processing accomplished using Athena software. 2.3 Electrochemical experiments and determination of products 2.3.1 Electrochemical experiments All electrochemical tests were conducted using a CHI-730E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments Company) with a standard three-electrode system. The carbon cloth loaded with the catalyst serves as the working electrode. A Hg/HgO electrode and a platinum electrode were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The cathodic chamber was filled with a 1 M NaOH + 0.1 M NaNO3 mixed solution, while the anodic chamber contained 1 M NaOH solution. The electrolyte was maintained under an Ar-saturated atmosphere during testing. The concentration of NH4 + generated in the electrolyte was determined using the indophenol blue method. The concentration of NO2 − in the reaction solution was measured by the Griess method. NO3 − concentration was measured under acidic conditions. 2.3.2 Determination of products (1) Detection of NH4 + The concentration of NH4 + generated in the electrolyte was determined using the indophenol blue method. The specific steps are as follows. The electrolyte was taken from the reaction cell and diluted to a detectable range. Then, 2 mL of the diluted electrolyte was mixed with 2 mL of 1 M NaOH solution containing 5 wt% salicylic acid and 5 wt% sodium citrate, followed by the addition of 1 mL of 0.05 M NaClO solution and 0.2 mL of 1 wt% sodium nitroprusside aqueous solution. The mixed solution was left to stand at room temperature for 2 h, after which the absorption spectrum was measured using an ultraviolet and visible (UV-Vis) spectrophotometer. The NH4Cl concentration was determined based on the characteristic absorption peak at 653 nm. The quantitative analysis was performed using a concentration-absorbance calibration curve plotted with ammonium chloride standard solutions. The fitted curve (y = 0.1x + 0.035, r 2 = 0.999) demonstrated a good linear relationship between absorbance and concentration. (2) Detection of NO2 − The concentration of NO2 − in the reaction solution was determined using the Griess method. The Griess reagent was prepared as follows. 0.1 g of N-(1-naphthyl) ethylenediamine dihydrochloride, 2.0 g of sulfanilamide, and 5 mL of phosphoric acid were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water. After diluting the electrolyte to a suitable detection range, 5.0 mL of the diluted solution was mixed with 0.1 mL of Griess reagent and allowed to react at room temperature for 20 min. The absorbance was measured at a wavelength of 540 nm using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer. Quantitative analysis was performed using a concentration-absorbance calibration curve plotted with sodium nitrite standard solutions. The fitted curve (y = 0.45x − 0.011, r 2 = 0.999) demonstrated a good linear relationship between absorbance and concentration. (3) Detection of NO3 − After diluting the electrolyte to a suitable detection range, 5.0 mL of the diluted solution was mixed with 0.1 mL of HCl solution and 0.01 mL of amidosulfonic acid solution (0.8 %), and the mixture was allowed to react at room temperature for 15 min. The absorbance was measured at wavelengths of 220 and 275 nm using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer. The final absorbance was calculated using the formula. (1) A = A 220 - 2 A 275 Quantitative analysis was performed using a concentration-absorbance calibration curve plotted with sodium nitrate standard solutions. The fitted curve (y = 0.031x − 0.025, r 2 = 0.999) demonstrated a good linear relationship between absorbance and concentration. Detailed electrocatalytic experimental procedures and the calculation of ammonia production rate and faradaic efficiency are provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of materials At 43.32° and 50.45° (Fig. 1 a), these peaks assigned to the (111) and (200) planes of Cu (No. 04-003-2953) were observed. Additionally, peaks at 44.15° and 51.44° are attributed to the (111) and (200) planes of Co (NO. 04-001-2681), indicating that the synthesized material consists of metallic copper and cobalt, with no detectable CoO phase, likely due to its low content. The triphasic material exhibits pronounced XRD peak broadening and reduced intensity compared to mono- and biphasic systems, indicating smaller crystallite sizes and higher defect densities. The interfacial network formation among Cu, Co, and CoO particles was clearly observed in the TEM image (Fig. 1b). A well-developed network of interfaces was evidenced by the distinct phase boundaries visible at high resolution. The spacings of the lattice (0.209 and 0.205, 0.201 nm) were assigned to Cu (111) and Co (111), respectively. The 0.242 nm corresponded to the CoO (101). A core-satellite structure is revealed in Fig. 1(c and d), where Cu forms large central cores surrounded by smaller Co and CoO particles [33]. This core-satellite configuration may promote synergistic interactions among the three components. The electrocatalytic performance is consequently enhanced through this configuration. As demonstrated in Fig. 1(e and f), single-phase Cu@C consists of well-dispersed particles, whereas biphasic Co/CoO@C forms partially interconnected interfacial networks. Electrocatalytic reactions typically occur on the surface of the catalyst surface or in the interfacial regions [28,29], which implies that the high interfacial density in the triphasic material likely serves a critical role in the nitrate reduction reaction (NO3RR). EDS mapping images for monophasic Cu@C and biphasic Co/CoO@C are available in the Supporting Information (Figs. S1 and S2). TEM analysis reveals pronounced lattice distortions at metal-carbon and intermetallic interfaces in Cu/Co/CoO@C, confirming strong interfacial interactions (Fig. 1g and Fig. S3). Raman spectroscopy reveals a substantially increased I D/I G ratio in the triphasic material compared to mono-/biphasic counterparts (Fig. S4), confirming elevated defect density within the carbon matrix. These collective characterizations verify the abundant defect structures inherent to the multiphase interface material, beneficial for the mass transfer and charge transport, thereby boosting reaction efficiency. 3.2 Electronic structure modulation The C 1s spectra for the three catalysts are shown in Fig. S5. Fig. 2 (a) displays the O 1s spectra of three catalysts. The biphasic (Co/CoO@C) and triphasic (Cu/Co/CoO@C) systems exhibit metal-oxide structures compared to the monophasic metallic Cu@C, with Cu introduction significantly increasing the oxide phase content. The Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 peaks of Cu0 were exhibited at 932.9 and 952.7 eV (Fig. 2b) [34]. A negative shift is observed in the triphasic material, indicating interfacial charge redistribution that induces electron accumulation at Cu sites. These strong interfacial electronic interactions lead to significant modification of the Cu electronic structure [35,36]. Simultaneously, metallic Co states are confirmed by peaks at 778.7 eV (Co 2p 3/2) and 793.8 eV (Co 2p 1/2) [37]. In contrast, the 781.3 and 796.3 eV peaks can be assigned to the Co(II) 2p 3/2 and Co(II) 2p 1/2 [38]. That indicates the presence of cobalt oxide species (Fig. 2c). Compared to Co/CoO@C, a positive binding energy offset has been observed for Cu/Co/CoO@C. This may be a sign that the electron-deficient states at Co/CoO sites collaborate with electron-rich states at Cu sites to establish a bidirectional charge transfer channel. The strong interfacial interactions modulate electronic structures, thereby optimizing the E ads of reaction intermediates [39]. More complex total density of states distribution (DOS) (Fig. 2d and e) of Cu/Co/CoO reflects the synergistic effects of the electronic states of multiple elements, providing possibilities for diverse interactions with reactants and intermediates. The d-band center of Cu/Co/CoO (total: −1.902 eV, Cu: −1.266 eV) is closer to the EF than that of Cu (−2.558 eV) (Fig. S6), which means that the electronic structure of Cu/Co/CoO@C can be optimized by building a three-phase interface. It is generally attributed to the increase in the adsorption capacity of intermediates [40]. The strong p-d orbital hybridization (Co 3d and O 2p) facilitates interfacial electron transfer from Co to O, creating a localized polarized electric field (Fig. 2f). This charge redistribution enhances the activation of NO3 − species and promotes subsequent reaction steps [41]. To further verify interfacial electron transfer and strong p-d orbital coupling in CoO, we conducted Bader charge analysis (Tables S1–S3). Pronounced charge redistribution occurs at the Cu/Co, Cu/CoO, and Co/CoO interfaces. These interfacial charge transfers collectively demonstrate the redistribution mechanism. They provide crucial electronic-level evidence for orbital coupling effects. The Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of the single-phase Cu@C and triphasic Cu/Co/CoO@C materials (Fig. 3 a) and first-order derivative curve (Fig. S7a) show excellent agreement with the spectrum of Cu foil, confirming that Cu exists in the metallic state in both catalysts. Notably, the slightly reduced white-line intensity of Cu in Cu/Co/CoO@C compared to Cu foil indicates an electron-rich state of Cu, which is consistent with the XPS results. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum (Fig. S7b) exhibits a prominent main peak (∼2.4 Å), attributed to the contribution of Cu–Cu. In Fig. 3(b), the Co K-edge XANES spectra of the biphasic Co/CoO@C and triphasic Cu/Co/CoO@C materials demonstrate that the valence state of Co lies between metallic Co0 and oxidized Co2+. The shift in the absorption edge of Co after the introduction of Cu confirms the existence of strong electronic interactions between the metal components. The EXAFS spectrum in Fig. 3(c) further verifies the coexistence of Co–Co and Co–O coordination shells, where the significantly enhanced intensity of the Co–O peak in Cu/Co/CoO@C provides direct evidence for the aforementioned p-d orbital coupling between Co and O. Through wavelet transform (WT) analysis of the Cu K-edge EXAFS (Fig. 3d–f), the characteristic signals of Cu–Cu metallic bonds can be clearly identified. Similarly, WT analysis of the Co K-edge EXAFS detects contributions from both Co–Co and Co–O bonds, but the Co–Co signal dominates, indicating that Co tends to form a metallic coordination environment (Fig. 3g–i and Fig. S8b). The first-derivative curve (Fig. S8a) further reveals closer alignment between the catalyst and Co foil. These results collectively reveal the critical role of interfacial electronic modulation and orbital hybridization in enhancing the catalytic performance of multiphasic materials. 3.3 NO3RR performance and mechanism analysis The potential of catalysts in NO3RR can be discovered through the phenomenon of increased current density (Fig. 4 a) with the addition of NO3 −. The onset potential of Cu/Co/CoO@C (146 mV) is more positive than that of Co/CoO@C (76 mV) and Cu@C (35 mV). Moreover, Cu/Co/CoO@C exhibits higher current density at the same potential. That means it may have excellent NO3RR performance. To optimize the preparation process, the effects of different joule heating modes (rapid heating and programmed heating) and temperatures on the performance of the material were compared (Figs. S9–S11 and Tables S4, S5). It is found that the material prepared by rapid heating to 1600 °C exhibits the best performance. The results of chronoamperometry measurements at different potentials for 1 h (Fig. 4b and c) show that at −0.4 V vs. RHE, Cu/Co/CoO@C achieves NH3 yield (Y NH3) = 2.03 mmol h−1 cm−2 and FE = 98.4 %, significantly outperforming Cu@C and Co/CoO@C (Fig. S12a). At −0.4 V vs. RHE, the Faraday efficiency reached its maximum. Nearly complete conversion of NO2 − to NH3 was achieved. Moreover, it surpasses most reported CuCo-based catalysts (Table S6). Product quantification employed colorimetric methods, with standard curves for NH4 +, NO3 −, and NO2 − established using UV-Vis spectrophotometry (Figs. S13–S15). As shown in Fig. 4(b and c), the NO3RR performance of the three catalysts exhibits significant differences, suggesting a potential synergistic catalytic effect between the three phases. Given the special role of NO2 − in the reaction, an experiment about NO2 − reduction was designed and implemented. As shown in Fig. 4(f), the FE(NO2 − → NH4 +) of Cu/Co/CoO@C and Co/CoO@C is similar and significantly higher than that of Cu@C. Moreover, the FE(NO3 − → NH4 +) of the Cu/Co/CoO@C catalyst far exceeds that of the Co/CoO@C catalyst at the same potential. According to the results, a synergistic effect was speculated to exist between Cu and Co/CoO. The two-step reaction proceeds in a tandem relay manner. (1) Cu dominates the NO3 − → NO2 − stage; (2) Co/CoO dominates the NO2 − → NH4 + stage. At wide NO3 − concentrations (Fig. 4d), Cu/Co/CoO@C exhibits excellent FE (86.1 %–98.4 %) and high-level ammonia production. To verify the accuracy of the colorimetric methods, ion chromatography (IC) detection was chosen as an auxiliary (Fig. 4e). According to the results of IC, the data of UV are confirmed to be convincing. Additionally, the FE (∼90 %) and Y NH3 of Cu/Co/CoO@C remain stable after 10 cycles (Fig. 4g). In-situ Raman spectrum was selected for the research of intermediates. The intensity of NO3 − peak (1046 cm−1) [42] gradually decreases with increasing potential, indicating the consumption of NO3 − (Fig. 5 a–c). The peaks at 1125 [43], 1501, 1543 [42], and 1590 cm−1 [44] correspond to the NO2 −, *NH, *NOH, and *NH3 intermediates, respectively. Comparing the results, the triphasic Cu/Co/CoO@C (Fig. 5c) exhibits the best NO3RR performance, showing the fastest nitrate consumption rate and significantly stronger characteristic peaks of reaction intermediates (*NH, *NOH, and *NH3) compared to the biphasic Co/CoO@C (Fig. 5b). Notably, although the biphasic material shows slower nitrate conversion, it can effectively transform nitrite into subsequent intermediates, demonstrating good reaction selectivity. In contrast, the monophasic Cu@C (Fig. 5a) only rapidly generates nitrite without effective further conversion, indicating poor NH4 + selectivity. This phenomenon, combined with prior characterization results (Fig. 2f and Fig. 3c), reveals the specific contributions of this triphasic interface structure: Cu sites dominate the step of NO3 − to NO2 −, while Co/CoO contributes to the subsequent reaction of NO2 − to NH4 +. Simultaneously, the strong p-d orbital coupling in CoO enhances NO3 − adsorption, facilitating the overall reaction. The superior performance of the triphasic material can be attributed to (1) abundant phase interfaces providing sufficient active sites and (2) a unique core-satellite structure (Cu core with Co/CoO satellites) facilitating electron transfer. The behaviors of the *NH and *NOH peaks suggest that the reaction follows the NOH pathway. In situ FTIR was conducted to further validate the chemical pathway (Fig. 5d–f), with the corresponding two-dimensional contour images shown in Fig. 5(g–i). The peak at 1146 cm−1 corresponds to the *NH2 [45], while the downward peak at 1174 cm−1 is caused by the stretching and bending of the N–H bond in NH3 [46], further confirming the generation of NH3. The peak at 1223 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of *NO2 [47]. It is evident that this peak gradually weakens as the reaction progresses, indicating the rapid consumption and transformation of the byproduct *NO2. The combination of in situ FTIR and Raman spectroscopy results further supports that the reaction follows the NOH pathway: *NO3 → *NO3H → *NO2 → *NO2H → *NO → *NOH → *N → *NH → *NH2 → *NH3. The in situ FTIR results also demonstrate superior NO3RR performance of the triphasic material. In the differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) signals (Fig. 6 a, b), m/z 2, 14, 15, 16, 17, 30, and 31 correspond to H2, *N, *NH, *NH2, *NH3, *NO, and *NOH intermediates, respectively [48–50]. The results confirm that the reaction follows the NOH pathway, consistent with both in situ FTIR and Raman spectroscopic observations. Compared to the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) (Fig. S16), during the NO3RR process, the peak of *H2 is relatively weak, while the signal intensities of *NH2 and *NH3 are significantly stronger, even overshadowing the peaks of other reaction intermediates such as *NO and *NOH (Fig. 6b and c). This demonstrates that the synthesized material possesses a superior ability to suppress hydrogen evolution and exhibits a greater propensity towards the reaction pathway for ammonia synthesis. Moreover, the pronounced signal intensities of the *NH2 and *NH3 peaks indicate that the reaction is efficient and the product formation is rapid. When designing electrocatalysts, mass transfer is one of the critical factors to consider [51]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results (Fig. 6d) reveal that Cu/Co/CoO@C exhibits excellent charge transport capability with the smallest charge transfer resistance (R ct). It is generally believed to improve reaction kinetics [52,53]. The double layer capacitance (C dl) value (Fig. 6e) reflects the slope of the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements (Fig. S17) were performed in the non-Faradaic potential region (0.83–0.93 V vs. RHE). The largest one is observed with Cu/Co/CoO@C. This is likely due to the abundant multi-phase interfaces in the material, which provide ample active sites and significantly enhance the mass transfer process [54]. To better understand the superior performance of the Cu/Co/CoO@C, adsorption configurations of the Cu/Co/CoO interface and a single Cu surface were constructed based on characterization results. The electronic states at the phase interface were analyzed (Fig. 6f). Differential charge density analysis (Fig. 6f) shows significant electron migration polarization at the Cu/Co/CoO interface (red and green regions indicate electron accumulation and electron depletion), suggesting that the reaction primarily occurs at the interface. The results (Fig. 6g) demonstrate that Cu/Co/CoO exhibits significant thermodynamic advantages in NO3RR, with a greater overall ΔG decrease from the initial state to the formation of * + NH3(g) and a lower final state free energy, indicating a more favorable reaction pathway [55]. In the key step of NO3 → NO3H conversion, the ΔG decrease of Cu/Co/CoO is significantly greater than that of the single Cu surface, suggesting stronger NO3 − activation capability. Although Cu shows an advantage in the step from NO3H to *NO2, the subsequent steps reveal that CuCoOCo exhibits a more stable and lower free energy change. This ensures steady progress of the reaction toward ammonia generation. Rate-determining step (RDS) analysis reveals that the *NO3 adsorption step is the RDS of the entire reaction. The ΔG increase for the RDS of Cu/Co/CoO (0.37 eV) is significantly lower than that of the Cu surface (0.62 eV). This lower energy barrier correlates with stronger NO3 − adsorption on the surface, potentially promoting subsequent reaction progression. The evolution of key intermediate adsorption configurations during the NO3RR on Cu/Co/CoO@C (Fig. S18) reveals that the reaction pathway follows a sequential hydrogenation process: *NO3 → *NO3H → *NO2 → *NO2H. Notably, the *NO2 intermediate exhibits a distinct adsorption configuration transition on the catalyst surface. Initially, it binds to active sites through two oxygen atoms, and then undergoes a configuration inversion during subsequent hydrogenation steps, transforming into a top-coordinated *NO2H intermediate through nitrogen atom bonding with active sites (Fig. 6g). For subsequent hydrogenation steps, this configuration transition markedly lowers the activation energy barrier. The Zn-NO3 − battery efficiently generates electricity while converting nitrate (NO3 −) into value-added ammonia (NH3), demonstrating significant environmental benefits. Leveraging the excellent NO3RR performance of the Cu/Co/CoO@C, we assembled a Zn-NO3 − battery using this material and a zinc (Zn) foil (Fig. 7 a). The battery archived and remained stable at 1.31 V versus Zn/Zn2+ for 24 h (Fig. 7b). As the discharge voltage decreased, the current density gradually increased (Fig. 7c). The maximum power density of 52.09 mW cm−2 was achieved at 89.81 mA cm−2, surpassing most reported Zn-NO3 − batteries (Table S7). Rate capability was evaluated at various current densities. The stable discharge profiles confirm the excellent rate performance (Fig. 7d). The maximum Y NH3 of battery achieved 297.5 µmol h−1 cm−2 with FE of 94.5 % (Fig. 7e) at 20 mA cm−2. This simultaneously enables efficient ammonia synthesis and power output. We performed galvanostatic charge-discharge (GCD) testing to assess cycling stability (Fig. 7f). The battery maintained a stable output voltage over a 24-hour test period with 10 mA cm−2. Further discharge tests at different current densities verified its stability. Even after high-rate discharge at 50 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage readily recovered at lower current densities of 20, 10, 8, 6, 4, and 2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7g). These results strongly demonstrate excellent cycling stability and robust structural stability of the Zn-NO3 − battery. 4 Conclusions This study successfully synthesized monophasic (Cu@C), biphasic (Co/CoO@C), and triphasic materials (Cu/Co/CoO@C), with the triphasic material exhibiting exceptional performance (Y NH3 = 2.03 mmol h−1 cm−2, FE = 98.4 % at −0.4 V vs. RHE). The Zn-NO3 − battery based on the Cu/Co/CoO@C delivers a power density of 52.09 mW cm−2 and a FE of 95.4 % for NH3 production. The enhanced activity stems from synergistic mechanisms driven by multiphase interface engineering. First, charge redistribution at Cu-Co/CoO interfaces optimizes intermediate adsorption energies, suppressing competing reactions. Second, a unique core-satellite structure enables synergistic catalysis between Cu and Co/CoO sites. Third, interfacial polarization via Co-O p-d coupling, combined with defect-driven mass transport and abundant active sites, synergistically enhances reaction kinetics. This research offers new insights into further exploration of multi-phase-interface NO3RR electrocatalytic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The nitrate reduction via electrochemical catalysis offers an environmentally friendly method for sustainable ammonia production and wastewater remediation. However, conventional Co-based catalysts suffer from a major limitation: their nitrate (NO3 −) adsorption capacity remains weak. This drawback severely restricts their catalytic efficiency. To overcome this limitation, we synthesized a triphasic interface material (Cu/Co/CoO@C) via rapid joule heating and elucidated its performance-enhancing mechanisms. The exceptional catalytic performance originates from the phase interface-induced multiscale structural regulation. At the microscopic scale, electronic structure modulation through interfacial charge redistribution between Cu and Co/CoO significantly reduces intermediate adsorption energies. Co 3d and O 2p orbitals coupling generates a localized polarized electric field, enhancing NO3 − activation. At the macroscopic scale, defect-rich structures improve mass transfer and expose abundant active sites. With the Cu/Co/CoO@C, the yield of NH3 is achieved to 2.03 mmol h−1 cm−2 (−0.4 V vs. RHE, Faradaic efficiency (FE) 98.4 %). The assembled Zn-NO3 − battery delivered a maximum power density of 52.09 mW cm−2 and a NH3 production rate of 297.5 µmol h−1 cm−2 (FE 95.4 %). Based on these results, this work offers new insights into multiphase interface design.
